Comment: Kidnapping, theft, and many other infractions are violations of state and local laws, so naturally, state and local law enforcement act in these cases. They may, when requested by federal agencies, assist in enforcement of federal laws, but they may not initiate the enforcement of such laws and are not required to do so. In Arpaio's case, he was enjoined by federal courts not to take certain actions and he violated a court order. You notice that Colorado law enforcement is enforcing state law regarding cannabis, not federal law. Right-wingers would spare themselves a lot of angst if they familiarized themselves with the actual Constitution, instead of the imaginary right-wing Constitution in their head.

Comment: Intermittentcy may well be a challenge, but where I live (and I suspect in most of Canada) the wind does, in fact, often blow at night! Offshore wind power is less prone to these problems and than onshore.

In Denmark, over 42% of the country's total energy consumption is covered by wind. While wind and solar are intermittent, a widely distributed smart grid along with the use of other power sources (tidal power, geothermal, and hydro) could compensate for this. In Europe, several countries have successfully integrated renewable energy on a large scale.

Comment: Trump's decision is self-serving. He aches for approval, and he knows his base (as well as others, such as yourself) will stroke his ego. He panders and postures, but the last thing Trump does is make rational decisions. You should be able to see that for yourself by now.

As far as the "wild-eyed hatred," you are far out of line on that claim. Nobody I know is bothered enough to muster up the emotional energy to actually hate him. Hate requires a lot of work, and if you choose to hate someone or something, there has to be a good reason. There is nothing, or very little, a rational person gains by hating another person, and because we recognize that, we reserve hate for only the most awful things we encounter in life.

It seems, on the other hand, that Trump supporters are eager to expend their energy on hate (for example, hatred of Hillary, foreigners, global warming, and curiously, trade deficits), and I suppose that is why you use the term so glibly.

Comment: If you are referring to the Pontifical Scripture Commission, they have no Magesterial authority.  They can only report the conclusions of their research.  No theologian has Masgesterial authority.  Theologians are more like lawyers--in the sense that they argue their case.  They do not have the final word on the case, however.  That authority lies with the judge.  In this case the pope and bishops are like the judges.  They are the ones who make a definitive decision regarding what the theologians have reported.  

The Church at ecumenical council and or the pope when he defines something are like the Supreme Court. Once the Church has spoken, the case is closed.  In the case of women priests, it might be arguable whether JPII issued a papal definition of a doctrine.  What is not arguable is that the teaching is infallible.  In other words--JPII likely just reiterated what the Church has always believed.

These costs don't include HST on building materials and independent contractor fees and provincial and municipal land transfer taxes .  The "solutions" introduced by the Wynne government will fail as they simply don't address the real problem which is the lack of supply caused by both provincial and municipal government policies.  It is basic economics that prices will rise if demand outstrips supply.

Comment: While I do my best to lower my carbon footprint (for example, by not owning a car), individual action alone cannot lower our collective carbon footprint sufficiently. We need to create a green infrastructure so that we reduce, and eventually eliminate, our dependence on fossil fuels. These changes need to happen at a systemic level. That is one reason why we should not be investing in pipelines and similar fossil fuel infrastructure which essentially serve to lock us into "business as usual." A pipeline only makes economic sense if we plan to use it for the next 40 years or so. Ecologically speaking, we cannot afford to do that. Why not instead invest that money in public transit, electrifying railroads, building energy-efficient buildings, and developing alternative energy sources instead?

Comment: VAT moves the tax burden from corporate income (and personal income) to consumption and does so in an open and observable manner. The US dollar is unlikely to move sufficiently to offset its impact to the US consumer, nor are factories likely to return quickly enough to provide jobs to stave off the impacts of high inflation to the poorest Americans.  It will not solve issues with gaming transfer prices.  It goes against WTO policy.  I see nothing to like about it.

The civil war in Syria started when Assad's security forces arrested and tortured some children for putting anti-Assad graffiti on a wall.

Multiple resistance groups - local rebels, religious (Sunnis, other Shia) and ethnic militias, ISIS, Al-Qaeda/Al-Nusra, the Free Syrian Army and more - organized and rose up against the Assad dictatorship.

The civil war didn't start because "The West supported the "good people" (later we learned they were actually head choppers) fighting Assad.".

It was already being waged before foreign support for the rebels arrived.

The Syrian Civil War started because the Assad regime had brutalized Syrians for 45 years.

And the biggest foreign players in this war aren't "The West", they're Russia and Iran.

Accuracy counts.

Comment: Hi. I don't think the argument here is that academics have to shut up in more popular fora (This author himself is writing an op-ed!), but rather that universities need to recognize what type of public engagement they want to encourage. Regardless of how McGill behaved (and frankly I think they behaved terribly), if academics write wearing their 'academic' hat--ie, using the authority of their post to claim expertise for their claims--then they have to hold themselves to higher standards than Wente-types. If an academic wants to engage in silly jokes and lazy stereotypes on their own time, they can do so as citizens. But they shouldn't present that as 'expertise'. McGill should never have gotten involved in disciplining Potter, but he also embarrassed himself and brought disrepute to his institution.

Comment: I think you have presented an important component of 21st century grids –minigrids. Minigrids are the way things are evolving where there are remote locations where central power is not easy and has not come.  They start with some solar panels and even old fashioned batteries with modern solid state devices that use low current DC like cell phones and LEDs. Low current and low voltage with 12V or 24V which the whole automotive/RV world operates on.
We have DC minigrids now that are in things like sever stations that operate at 380 VDC.  A lot of saving not doing AC to DC conversions both in terms of electrical efficiency and heat n the case of server stations. We need good home wiring and grid standards to allow these efficiencies to be added.
There are multiple forms of storage both at the home level and the larger minigrid level.

All of Obama's programs added a modest total of $983 Billion to the national debt during his two terms-- he might have spent more but was blocked by Congress and budget sequestration. Comment: It's hard to imagine Canadian courts finding such a law to be constitutionally valid, especially when it comes to using public services.

They've already dealt with a case involving a niqab-wearing woman  using a public service - testifying in court.  The Supreme Court of Canada found there were certain circumstances where the accused's right to a fair trial meant the witness should be unveiled, but went on to add:

"However, never permitting a witness to testify wearing a niqab would not comport with the fundamental premise underlying the Charter  that rights should be limited only to the extent that the limits are shown to be justifiable.  The need to accommodate and balance sincerely held religious beliefs against other interests is deeply entrenched in Canadian law."

~ R v N.S [2012, SCC} at:
 https://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/12779/index.do?r=AAAAAQAFbmlxYWIB

Comment: I'm one of the part-time professors who is now laid-off due to the strike (I'm not part of the union because I teach too many hours, if that makes any sense). I teach various subjects in the engineering technology field and I currently work at two different colleges (depending upon the semester). 

I essentially teach full-time however I have to re-apply for a new contract each semester. There are very few-full-time faculty left at either college because as they retire they are replaced by people like me. I am not paid for course development, marking, or meeting with the students out-side of the class time. I have no benefits or pension. When I create course content (presentations, tests, exams etc., that I am not paid for) then I have to give it to the college with no assurance that I will teach it the next semester.

I believe that the union is right in this case.  The college administration is full of incompetence and nepotism.

Comment: That's the key question.  Did Smith KNOW for certain where his fellow officers were?  How could he know their exact location?  This wasn't like firing at someone thru a wood picket fence, where you can sort of see thru the slats to figure out who or what's on the other side.  These are floorboards in a house, tight up against each other -- possibly with linoleum or carpeting on top of the boards.  It seems unlikely that he'd even be able to see a muzzle flash from where he was inside the house.  He probably just fired repeatedly (10 rounds according to the article) in the general vicinity of whatever hole was made by the suspect's gunshot up into the house.  He made an assumption that the suspect hadn't moved, and was still in the same spot.  But it could have just as easily been an officer down there trying to close in on the suspect.  The point is: Smith couldn't be sure.  He was guessing.  And that could have ended very badly.

Comment: GIP Main, I'm having trouble seeing exactly where the problems are with the proposed changes.  Most business owners that I have talked to, aren't affected.  Even some people I know that have groused about the changes, don't specifically know what the implication will be for their tax picture.  And then there is a wide variety of anecdotal information on tax hits on forums such as this, but no details are ever supplied.  The Globe ran a rather exhaustive analysis on a number of scenarios, and again, no significant impact on most earners.  The only ones impacted seem to be very high earners who are using a corporate structure purely to save on tax.  And that's not wrong, but there is a rule that Revenue Canada can reverse any strategy which is purely to save tax.  So I'm just trying to figure out what the actual problem is.  No one seems able to say it in the simple form of - "this rule means that for this income this much extra tax will be paid" - and then explain why that is unfair.

Comment: Simply put, you cannot run an airline profitably by selling a transatlantic ticket for $600. the math doesn't work and never has. The earlier, profitable days of air travel, the fares were beyond the reach of most middle class folk, a crappy fact but true, but the fares reflected cost. When the budget carriers came along in the '70's and '80's they took a bite out of the major carriers who responded buy cutting fares to match, hoping to put them out of business. It didn't work. Flying customers came to believe that these below-cost fares were normal. The major airlines finally figured out that they couldn't make money at this rate, so they loaded more passengers into tighter rows increased occupancy and charged for extras. Who's at fault it's not the passenger - it's the airlines for being poor strategists and reacting incorrectly to the budget carriers in the first place.

Having said that if you're flying to Florida for $400 you need to realize that you're getting a deal.

I see his refusals as a deliberate attempt to make himself into a martyr. For example, Acme Oilco sells their interest in Cook Inlet after pumping 85% of the estimated reserves.  Acme knows the pipelines are old, have not been pigged in decades and are prone to leaks.  Same goes for all the equipment that Acme sells Hilcorp.  Hilcorp knows the risks but decides the risk is worth the rewards, so they buy Acme's assets and known problems.  When a problem like leaking pipelines or failed equipment pops up, Hilcorp will take the least cost method of fixing the problem.  Maybe shutting down the line, etc.  The oil industry bottom feeders are what Alaska has in store for the future, expect more leaking pipes.

Comment: The reality is that few Americans or Canadians are inveterate racists and/or Nazis. Sure, there are racist rumps in both countries (although there is lingering culturally engrained anti-black racial animus, especially in parts of the American South, and pockets of anti-aboriginal animus in Canada), but placing broad restrictions on free speech to address the problem seems intended not to suppress the views these people espouse, and will continue to do among themselves, but to curb broader public discussion of contentious and in many cases very important public policy issues. It seems to me the cure the author proposes is worse than the disease being combatted. If the author doesn't recognize the implicitly anti-democratic implications of his draconian solution, I fear that where the cause of protecting and promoting democracy is concerned academia has abandoned the project.

Comment: Time for the public-recreation sector to sober up a bit?  We've got the PA pool currently asking the voters to fund a major expansion based on its usage growth in 2016, when the Sequim pool was closed.  And now we have the Sequim pool planning an expansion on the basis of one year's membership figures since their pool re-opened.

This kind of building project is expensive, and the bonds necessary to fund them leave a long-term public debt.  It's very unlikely that PA and Sequim both suddenly need a major expansion of their public swimming pools.  

As a lap-swimmer, I am all in favor of excess pool capacity, but as a taxpayer, I am NOT in favor of paying through the nose for unnecessary new construction.  It would seem sensible for both facilities to collect a few more years of data before they ask us to commit to multi-millions of dollars in new building debt.

Comment: "Prohibition doesn’t work. We should legalize (and regulate) all drugs."

Amen, Mr Picard. Countless billions of dollars into enforcement and prosecution, that doesn't seem to have any effect in reducing demand or diminishing availability of drugs. All it does is raise the price, which fuels organized crime, and drives addicts (who in many places have limited legal avenues to get help) to other forms of crime in order to feed their habits. There is no upside to prohibition.

We have been incredibly successful about reducing use of cigarettes, which have never been prohibited. The futility of the war on drugs in so obvious, and the potential for redirecting those billions of dollars into measures that might actually help people get off of drugs, makes the current approach seem like society is on a century-long acid trip.

Comment: This is a good one.  Thanks to Doug Saunders for this.  

"The exhibition’s president, W.H. Evans, asked them to remain standing to sing the national anthem – and then chaos ensued, as half the audience broke into God Save the Queen ..."  Wow.  That puts the time into perspective!  Personally, I would have opted to start singing Gordon Lightfoot's new Canadian Railroad Trilogy: 

"But time has no beginnings and hist'ry has no bounds
as to this verdant country they came from all around
They sailed upon her waterways and they walked the forests tall
built the mines, mills and the factories for the good of us all ...

Look away said they, across this mighty land
from the eastern shore to the western strand"

Lyric sheets would have been necessary.  Lightfoot debuted it in a special CBC broadcast on January 1, 1967.  The heartfelt, evocative song may endure as the most meaningful part of the entire Centennial celebration.  At least, it is for me.

Comment: Steve, I have no problem whatsoever with people taking what is rightfully theirs.  Working for a fair wage or turning an ethical profit is what makes the economy hum.

What bothers me is those who shamelessly exploit others and subscribe to the philosophy that the strong do what they can and the weak suffer what they must.  That was the mantra when I was at university in the early 80s, and it brought Reaganomics, junk bonds, and irresponsible cuts, which were the gestation of the decline of the middle class and the increasing gap between rich and poor.

I have a comfortable lifestyle by dint of hard work.  But I don’t object to society helping those who aren’t as fortunate as I am; we weren’t all blessed with good health and reasonable intellect.  I don’t grumble too much about the taxes I have to pay, either – while I deplore the waste I see in government, I also see people who would have neither food nor shelter if it weren’t for publicly funded programs.

Comment: If the author is concerned about productivity, then the most effective step is to reduce congestion in our urban areas.
.
Congestion is an enormous tax that hobbles labour force mobility, and increases the transaction costs of every economic activity that involves getting goods, services, or personnel to the right place at the right time.
.
Congestion hugely constrains economic choice:  If you can't be sure that your delivery driver can get back from Oakville before the end of the day, you waste  a lot of your time trying to plan delivery routes and schedules to avoid traffic, and you are less likely to do business in, e.g., Oakville.
.
It effects, and limits, economic choices.
.
The solution is European-intensity public transit.
.
But that is what the Oil-company-owned Conservatives have spent two decades fighting tooth-and-nail to prevent because Oil companies profit from congestion  - at the expense of the entire population.
.
It is a huge tax.
It is a productivity killer.

Comment: Boulder's city gubmit has wrestled with the problem of affordable housing for decades, but it is largely a delusion. As long as we tax property, without regard to means, based on how much someone else would pay for it whether the owner wants to sell it or not, rising property taxes will always render all property less and less affordable through time. This is a kind of economic cleansing. In Boulder, we have the paradox of the few low income persons who have managed to hold onto a residence subject to escalating taxes in part to support programs intended to provide affordable housing for people who actually have higher incomes than they do. An enlightened property tax system would consider means and freeze property-related taxes on the sole primary residence of persons of limited means until such property is sold or transferred. Absent that, affordable housing schemes remain rather ironic.

Comment: A few weeks ago the head of Canada's largest lumber company West Fraser stated that the fires were not burning much merchantable timber. The fires are primarily burning trees that were killed years ago by the pine beetle. All it took was a hot dry season to torch these very dry dead trees.

The pine beetle infestation was caused years ago by a failed forest management practice in a large provincial park-South Tweedsmuir. A previous NDP government tried to defy Mother Nature. A mature pine forest burns and regenerates as part of the natural cycle. Extinguishing all fires and using no alternatives such as controlled burns led to the pine beetle problem. Unfortunately the beetles didn't stay on the park.

The NDP is currently concerned about tanker accidents & the release of carbon. Their past errors have resulted in a carbon release worse than any tanker spill could ever be.

Comment: Thank you for the comment; allow me to elaborate. My work on this topic has been misconstrued by many. It is clear beyond doubt that Elizabeth gave stirring testimony, the act was a significant step forward in our history, and that she and Roy deserve the honors they've received. It's also clear that apart from a quote in the next day's Juneau Empire, we don't know precisely what she said. The act and her role in its passage essentially disappeared from the public record for nearly three decades. It was so forgotten that when Elizabeth died in 1958, the obituary that appeared in the ANB's own newsletter made no mention of the act or her supposedly famous speech. The first account is a remembrance by Gruening twenty-nine years later. The rest of her speech was embellished by later writers. My goal is not to chip away at Elizabeth's legacy, only that we should be honest with ourselves about what we know and what we don't. An embellished myth may make us feel good, but it's not history.

Comment: Having worked as a poll watcher and as an election judge in my county, and witnessing how ballots are collected, counted, scrutinized, and recounted, I have trouble imagining how any kind of vast voter fraud would be accomplished.   That there could be some sort of enormous collusion amongst more than 3,000 counties in the U.S. to sway a Presidential election one way or another is preposterous.  Were voter fraud as common as some claim, then it would be easy to obtain a list of folks who voted, and compare it to the list of registered voters in your county.  A little research or footwork would easily reveal the dead, the non residents, and the non citizen, who voted…  especially if there was a large number of such.
I’m inclined toward the notion that this unnecessary, gratuitous attempt at federal centralization of voter information is just one more tactic to discourage Americans from voting…and they are succeeding, witness the number of citizens deregistering.

Comment: Hello GH - If I am understanding you correctly, you want the government to step in and tell unit owners they cannot rent out their units. If this is correct and you fear that your condo building will turn into an apartment building, you should probably sell your unit and rent/buy a house somewhere else. The government would be foolish to make any changes that you allude to in your post. First, the number of available rentals would likely decrease significantly, since roughly three times as many condo buildings as opposed to apartment buildings have been built over the past decade. Further, if these units are removed from the rental market, then the rental prices will increase (i.e., supply is less than demand). Second, condo purchases would likely decrease, since who would want to buy a unit if they cannot rent it out if needed. I hope the government does not do as you suggest they should.

Comment: It's ironic  -- with the council members who intend not to run, all that would be required to restore this council to sanity would be for Cherie Kidd to resign. 

But the fact remains  --  the PA City Council has gone seriously off the rails twice in twelve years.  And in our current configuration, when the council goes nuts, there is no countervailing power to check them.  If we had a mayor elected by the people, not by the council, there would at least be someone who could veto council's actions.

It is important to remember what brought us to this point.  People who wanted the original unilateral fluoridation decision to be decided by referendum met all the requirements for a citizen initiative to be put on the ballot, but the city council refused to do so.  When the courts decided the issue, the verdict was that citizens didn't have the right.  So warning us we'd lose our rights to initiatives and referenda is ironic, too  --  since we don't actually have them.

Comment: "I greet you as if you were an object."

Martin Buber wrote a book, I And Thou (the German title, Ich und du, is better, because "du" is still used as second person familiar, while there is really no longer a second person familiar in English).

Comment: The concept you are defining is called "overcharging" in the business.  And it clearly occurs.  But not just in Oregon Measure 11 crimes.

I believe that the arson conviction in Malheur by Frank Papagni of the two ranchers which resulted in mandatory minimum sentences  was an example that actually went to trial instead and that's why they went to jail for 5 years.  

As for the guilt/not guilty issue, as a prosecutor it was my job to only charge and convict the guilty.   Those are the ones I prosecuted,  There were more than enough guilty ones; prosecuting and convicting the innocent is not my style. 

But, if you have a dead victim, for example, and weak evidence  'overcharging' to the level you think you can barely prove if you have to is the way to go.  You can always go to trial and the jury/judge goes for the lesser included offense and they are convicted of criminally negligent homicide instead of manslaughter.  10 year felony or 5 year felony and the probable sentence in 3 years

Comment: I agree a change is needed, but to what? 
A system where MPs are beholden to their parties (closed list proportional)? 
A system that creates permanent minorities (straight proportional with no cut-off points)? 
A system where someone can cast a "moral" vote that does not count (ranked ballots)? 
A system where some people have more representative voting than others (rural-urban votes)? 
A system deemed too complicated (single transferable ballot)? 
A system requiring multiple ballots (various regional mixed-member proportional representation systems)?

We need to work on the replacement system, not just make a random decision on what the replacement should be.

Comment: As a dedicated train fan, I have to note that there is insufficient population in the southern Willamette valley to support massive spending on passenger transport - at least from a strictly numbers perspective.  We have missed very important chances to improve passenger train service.  If the interstates had incorporated dedicated passenger rail it would be great.   I can't see a pathway that will get us thriving intercity rail.  Maybe the best option is to design bus trains having multiple linked sections and train like accommodations that run on the interstates and connect directly to mass transit sites in the cities they serve.  Alternatively, nationalize all the nations tracks (not the rail companies) so as to maintain and deploy them in the public interest (like the interstates).  But sadly, I think we may have missed the boat on rail by massively subsidizing roads and airports.

Comment: One of the realities of food purchasing is that it isn't a science. That is most people don't consult research papers to decide what to eat and what to buy. This means that other kinds of human valuations factors come into play. The principle one for many people is: The more expensive something is the better it must be. That generally  applies to the perceived values of cars and houses and restaurants etc.. The "problem:" with conventionally grown food in Canada is that it is really cheap and that suggests that it can't really be very good. So people buy organic because they believe that its higher cost means it must be better in any number of ways.
When you show that judgment is wrong, it doesn't really matter because that fact doesn't address the "cheaper is not as good" mental paradigm people use to judge most things.
That may be very ironic, but Irony is the truest name of the food purchasing game in the Canada in the 21st century.

Comment: The last time the budget was "balanced" (by the PCs in 2003), it was actually balanced. That is, provincial debt did not go up year-over-year. This budget is not balanced, once all the capital spending that has been shuffled off-budget is included. Debt will increase by $12-13 billion dollars year-over-year. The credit rating agencies are fully aware of these tricks. From Standard and Poor's last credit rating downgrade in 2015: "The stable outlook reflects our expectation that, under our base-case scenario, Ontario will continue to make slow progress in reducing its after-capital deficit in the next two fiscal years..." Note those words: "after-capital deficit." That's what counts. It's still at $12.2 billion, about the average it's been over the years the Liberals have been in power, and higher when one-time "adjustments" and asset sales are taken out.

Comment: They are not.   The forms used to fortify food are based on what is cheap and stable that SHOULD be convertible in the body if genetics for the individual are "standard" as it relates to the compound involved, however, genetics are not standard with respect to folic acid conversion for about 50% of the population (or more).   Generally, folic acid is the synthetic form

Here's a page that illustrates chemical structures of folic acid, folate and folinic acid.
http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/vitamins/folate#definitions

It is possible now to purchase folate as a supplement (5-methyltetrahydrofolate), and it's more expensive than folic acid.   I suspect it's also somewhat less stable and less convenient.

Folic acid requires methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase to be "converted" to folate.   In many people, there are genetic anomalies referred to as MTHFR that impair this process, causing lots of health problems in a significant number of people.

Folic acid is just one example.

Comment: We continue to wonder what motivated the Las Vegas killer to do what he did.  Was he simply crazy?  What were his motives?
It’s as if we forget that environment affects behavior.  It only takes a moment to think how profoundly many of our daily actions result from our surroundings.(google “examples of how environment affects behavior”)
Now, imagine infecting your environment with literally dozens of guns, military weapons, handguns, ammo, and accompanying paraphernalia.  
So many guns can easily dominate anyone’s environment and can, thus, profoundly affect behavior. 
Why did the Las Vegas shooter use his guns?  It’s because he had them, and they affected him exactly as should be expected.
What practical lesson can we take from this?  Well, if you are anxious, angry, fearful, uneasy with the world, see enemies everywhere, try getting rid of your guns. Surround yourself with art, and beauty, and friendly people instead.

Comment: Your statement is a red herring.  Forestry's renewability doesn't stop BC from clear=cutting existing forests to about roughly 60 feet from the edge of a highway, and then leaving a thin strip of trees next to the highway, so that drivers passing by can't see the true extent of the clear-cut.

Comment: Bicycles are covered under the personal property section of standard homeowners & renters insurance policies (theft & damage, but not normal wear & tear). 

Homeowners & renters policies also provide liability protection for harm you may cause to someone else or to their property.  If the injured party decides to sue, you will be covered up to the liability limits. Minimum limits are usually set at $100,000 & can range as high as $1,000,000; with or without an umbrella policy attached.

In the event you injure someone while riding your bike, your home/renters policy normally includes no-fault medical coverage as well, usually ranging from $1,000 to $5,000. 

Not sure about the registration thing though. I do remember back in the 1960s in a suburban metro city in the Midwest, all bicycles driven in my town were required to have their bikes registered, and we even got a nice little license plate (3" X 5") to hang from our banana seats.

Comment: The number of listings rose dramatically due to a number of factors:
1) people clamouring to get their house on the market trying to cash in before the drop (wether it really happens or not, it's too early to tell)
2) many properties artificially listed low for an offer date, trying to entice a bidding war in May, didn't sell as planned.  Most of these sellers then re-listed their house at a higher price.  This counts as a separate listing, hence the inflated MLS listing numbers.

I bought and sold in the past 3 weeks - I actually think it's a great time to buy as I don't believe the "downturn" we're feeling now is gonna last all that long.  We bought our long term house, so even a drop for a number of years is no big deal.  As for our sale of a small detached in the GTA - we listed at a price that we thought was fair market value.  It sold in 24 hours with multiple competing offers.  I think the days of artificially listing low are done

Comment: The need for sisters has declined for a couple of reasons.

The massive overlapping patchwork of government social programs, with NGOs, and other programs - some funded by other churches, nongov's etc....has swooped in and done what the sisters used to do....teaching, rehabilitation programs, other forms of training, food banks, nursing, you name it.

No longer a need.

They also "disappeared" to the parishes...no one knows that there are sisters doing good nearby....because they live in apartments and don't wear habits.

So they have 'gravitated" to "causes"..Gramlich etc. etc..essentially becoming thorns in their bishop's side (and their own superiors). 

Given their invisibility..it's hard to raise funds to take care of them.

They are now consolidating with other orders to economize their own care.  10-15 years from now....they'll be no more. Maybe a few orders, contemplative, or the orthodox ones. 

Sad as it is, these are the facts. 

Net: the government has done away with them.

Comment: It's much simpler than that ...When political polls fail it is always due to 1 (or more ) of these 3 causes:
(1) biased samples that include an incorrect proportion of each candidate’s supporters; (2) change in voter preferences between the time of the poll and the election; or (3) incorrect forecasts about who will vote. It's this last element that causes more political polls to fail than any other...period. Accurately identifying likely voters is much more difficult that simply asking someone if they plan on voting in the next election... The biggest challenge for Election polls  is trying to produce a model of a hypothetical population that doesn't exist at the time the poll is conducted: the future electorate.

The polling I looked at closely so far used a Perry-Gallup type of index (to determine who the most likely voters were) that woefully underestimated the motivation to vote for Trump of those voters below the cutoff. Thankfully!

Comment: Thanks Tom, but it’s more than a try. Up until this past month the action committee was meeting every two weeks. We have talked with all types of groups involved; shooting, homeowners, hunters, trails,  ATV, etc.. We’ve talked with coffee clutches and people individually. Meetings are posted everywhere (including the papers). We have begun writing our own piece of legislation and management plan ourselves as there is no money for the state to do it. Marty Parsons from the DNR is helping with providing us feedback for that plan. Surveys of designation are being created to get an understanding of what area the agreement and legislation should include. The DNR and the Borough have provided maps of the area for the design.  A trip to Juneau, a web site, facebook page, a petition form, public awareness, community buy in and a lot of work is being accomplished here. No more accidental shooting deaths need occur.  All enthusiasts need to be able to respect each other and co-exist safely .

1. First of all, it’s airline spin to call this an overbooking. Comment: Trump took a completely legal deduction, otherwise the state and federal tax authorities would have made him pay the taxes. Criticizing Trump for taking a legal deduction is logically the same as saying he should have paid more than he was legally required to pay. Unless a person taking this stance pays more taxes than they are legally required to pay, or they at least require anyone they would vote for President to do so, then they are a hypocrite seeking a particular political outcome as the only reason for their hypocrisy.

By the way, no candidate for President is required to release their taxes. It's an option. When someone else obtains and releases them, it's a crime. That should be the story here, and we as citizens should not tolerate such a thing. We still get to vote for whomever we wish.

Comment: The comment from AC that "“miscommunication” occurred because the airline was not dealing directly with the family" gives only a small clue as to how this actually happened.  Who were they dealing with - a third party booking site?  Were all family members on one booking, or were they on several bookings?  Did the booking indicate that the 10 year old was in fact a minor, or was that information omitted?  Were they connecting to Costa Rica on AC or another airline?  Was the problem at OLCI that the son could not get a seat assignment, or that he could not check in at all?  The answers to all these questions are needed before it can be determined exactly what happened.  Splitting hairs maybe, but the son was never bumped per se - he likely could have obtained a boarding pass with GTE for seat assignment, and sorted it all out at the airport.  AC was certainly not responsive both before and after, but it is likely the bookings did not give a true picture of the actual party travelling.

Comment: There are many other issues at stake: 
The more governments have set up taxes, tariffs and controls, the more the private sector has sought to circumvent these constraints on their 'freedom of choice'. The barriers to entry are controlled by the governments. ANY Investment whether in a company, savings account or provident fund etc now carries a much higher cost threshold in order to make a decent return and as such the need to specialize in such structures places emphasis on returns for the individual investor and not the greater good of all. As such, there are now more funds than there are listed equities - more cash chasing fewer investments because of a lack of choice. This competition is bad for the masses as the State looks to take so much in the form of taxes.  
Capital will follow the path of least resistance for the highest return and the more the State looks to interfere in this process, the greater the attempt to bypass the State.

Comment: No. This is a common-law ruling about a common-law defense - it applies unless and until overruled by a higher court. The concourt could, if a case came before it, overrule and reverse this decision but until and unless that happens (and it won't because the ruling is absolutely correct) the precedent stands as the law of the land. That's how common-law works - when a judge rules that a common-law is no longer in sync with the values of society, or unconstitutional, or in contradiction with legislative law - then it ceases to be law and only a new court precedent can change that.
Even a small-town magistrate has that power (it was such a magistrate who made adultery no longer a punishable offense in the 1920s)

Creating a NEW common law offense works the same way but happens far less often as judges are naturally reticent about convicting somebody of an action they could not have known was a crime at the time they did it. So it requires a pretty egregious and obvious wrong.

Comment: With leaf vegetables I put a capful of laundry bleach in a gallon of cold water, rinse the leaves, use a salad spinner, rinse again in clean cold water, and spin it again. That will kill most germs and separate various insects and dirt, and what you don't use can be saved for later. Any vegetables you saute' or  stir-fry, just scrub the dirt off before chopping or pare off the bitter skin of carrots and parsnips. The cavity of commercial apples gets so much pesticide immersion that it should be cut out before eating, and I recommend peeling the skin, which may be waxed, if not recently sprayed.

Comment: A case for Koloa leading Polynesian explorers to the Hawaiian Islands

http://www.sterlingbirds.com/Leskiw/Discovery%20of%20Hawaiian%20Islands.html
.
Students of primitive navigation believe that the migration of birds had meaning for the Polynesians, and that they learned much from watching the flocks that gathered each year in the spring and fall, launched out over the ocean, and returned later out of the emptiness into which they had vanished. Harold Gatty believes the Hawaiians may have found their islands by following the spring migration of the golden plover from Tahiti to the Hawaiian chain, as the birds returned to the North American mainland.
.
 In 1778, Captain Cook was on his third expedition, seeking the elusive Northwest Passage. During late summer, in the North Pacific/Bering Sea, his crew spotted a Pacific Golden Plover, which seemed to be migrating south. Cook wondered if the birds knew something about geography that he didn’t. Possibly Cook was lead to Hawaii by Koloa.

Comment: I don't know any trolls personally but I  think I may met some inadvertently over the years. My kids all played minor hockey and when the  internet started going full blast about 1995, there were forums on their respective teams. The comments about the players , coaches and even the mothers on the teams was not very complimentary. Of course everybody posted anonymously, and some of the things said about the kids (male and female ) was downright criminal. 
Years later one of my son's was signed by an NHL team to an entry level contract and one of the assistant general managers on the NHL team actually quoted a personal slight about my son that he had read online. Suffice to say my son had a nice career but the damage had been done.  He went overseas and all of that crap vanished. 
The internet, because of people's anonymity is sometimes a cesspool of logic. Things we wouldn't say to stranger's faces are often brazenly posted online. I can see why online newspapers choose no forums.

Comment: We have plenty of feral cats in Aiea, and they quite clearly do not eat primarily out of trash cans, because trash cans are covered. Even in Mainland suburbia, where raccoons do eat out of trash cans, they do not eat primarily out of trash cans.

I frequently see feral cats hunting birds, anole lizards, and at least once saw one eat a large cockroach.

The Polynesian colonists brought rodents with them, yet the native birds seem to have survived them just fine. I suspect the mongoose is at least as serious an egg predator, and may be worse, at least for some species.

Cats are in no danger whatsoever of going extinct. That cannot be said of Hawaii's birds and monk seals.

So, it becomes a question of priorities. Do we want happy outdoor pet cats, or a thriving bird and seal population?

If anyone has a better solution to the cat problem than killing them, let's hear it. I'm open to any non-cruel solution. What I am not open to is more of the proven failure of TNR.

Comment: From the article, on Feb. 02, the patient claimed to be in pain from falling down the stairs.  An extensive workup was performed, including expensive imaging studies, with reportedly normal results. On Feb. 03, the patient returned, in pain, with meth. on her tox. Report.  Blood/ metabolic panels were performed. The physician found no basis for an infection which likely means she was afebrile with normal WBC. She was advised to f/up with her physician, which she apparently did not. FIVE DAYS later her chiropractor "discovers" her infection.   She is found to be septic.

The infection may very well have developed AFTER her ER visits. She also may have been seeking drugs, or was truly in pain from her fall. This is tragic for the family, but this physician did nothing wrong. These frivolous lawsuits contribute to the rising cost of healthcare.

Comment: "No shirt, no shoes, no service" does not violate the civil rights act. The law says you cannot discriminate against people based upon race, color, sex, religion, or national origin. 

"You must wear shoes" is not a discriminatory act. However, it is illegal to say "we don't serve mexicans," or "we don't serve christians," or "we don't serve women."

The issue of businesses denying homosexual people comes into it because it is sex discrimination. Saying "I won't serve you, because you're the wrong sex" is wrong, whether you're pointing at the customer or their spouse.

To make another example, let's imagine a pair of restaurants across the street from one another- one Kosher, one Halal. Either owner can decide not to eat at their neighbors restaurant, as is their right. But neither can refuse to serve the other based upon their differing religions. 

Does that make sense?

Comment: The intention was for the "loan" to be written off all along.  Bombardier has a very long history of not paying back Federal government "loans".

The only reason why it is referred to as a "loan" is so that our government can keep off-budget.  If it was termed a "grant" they would have to include it as spending on their budget and it would add to the deficit.  But if they call it a "loan" then it is not considered government spending according to our accounting rules and is kept off-budget.  The loan only comes on-budget at some point in the distant future when the government decided to write off that loan.

Also loans allow for vastly reduced transparency as the government can (and does) claim that they are not able to satisfy Access To Information requests regarding how much of the previous ~$1B in loans Bombardier has paid back.

This sort of behaviour proves that for Justin Trudeau and the Liberals "Open and Transparent government" is nothing more than an election slogan.

Comment: I understand that this is an AK newspaper, but the writer is showing an ignorance regarding Natives issues.  The author seems to take umbrage over AK having 40% of the total number of recognized tribes but no representation.  While I agree that AK Natives should be represented, that 40% is misleading.  When the government officially recognized AK Native tribes, they seemed to codify almost every separate native village as a separate tribe, which is radically different than how it was done with the Native American tribes where typically all the villages in an area with the same culture were grouped into a tribe.  That means that while there are fewer Lower 48 tribes, they are much larger.  Estimates place the total number of AK Natives living in AK right now as between 110,000-125,000.  If we were to consolidate those all into one tribe, it still wouldn't even break into the Top 5 of the largest federally-recognized tribes, and represents only about 2% of the total US Native population.

Comment: The subtitle and straw man argument on which you start your writing sends you off on the wrong direction.  The state of Alaska spends way too much money; it is that simple.  

The idea that keeping state spending high is going to save the state is entirely foolish.  Taking money from the public thorough dividends or taxes and having the state spend it will not save the economy.  The monies of the PFD or any taxes levied will be spent; the question is by who and for what.  

Just to pick one thing: we are spending around $16K per student in public schools.  For a family with three kids, that's $48K dollars.  About 2/3 of median household income, before taxes.  And for all that money, 10% of students find the schools so bad they choose to bear the burden of homeschooling.

Lets do the hard work first and fix our spending problems, then we can figure out how to fund what we really want, and can afford.

Comment: What does all this discussion of charters have to do with Colorado?  The most desirable school district in the state, Cherry Creek, has only ONE charter school that was built in the 1990's.  It succeeds almost only with well-funded neighborhood schools that have stable, happy teaching staffs.  Colorado has a formula for success of public education in wealthy neighborhoods (which it should).  In targeted areas with students mired in difficult life circumstances, charters with a high expectation/high support format (even partial week boarding) are an excellent use of Other People's Money.  However, it would be enlightened non-profit organizations, rather than the free market, to whom we should turn to develop this type of school.

Comment: I want no part of it. I don't see any advantage at all to working-class people in a rivalry with competing empires. I spent four years in the Navy, fortunately before Vietnam got hot. Two of my nephews have been in the military, one in Afghanistan. It's mostly working-class guys who get out of high school with no other prospects who join the military. They're being exploited.

Comment: Richmond,
  Legal age of consent laws are not values, they are laws. They can be based on an underpinning value, but laws are not values in of themselves. Religious beliefs are indeed not allowed to circumvent this, and if the challenged the Charter on this, they would probably lose. But they do have the right to make a Charter claim on such grounds if they could make a religious case, which is doubtful.  So, basically, I think you are correlating laws with values incorrectly. Values do often underpin laws, but not always. We might be able to achieve unitary agreement on the need for age of consent laws, but even then there's debate on the appropriate age, meaning that, it's not in fact a unitary value as encoded in law. Reality is more complex than lofty ideals such as this.

Comment: This is nonsense on a number of levels.

First, the Yen carry trade is tiny in comparison to pre 2007.

Second, the trade is to borrow in Yen short term and invest in higher paying debt instruments like Aussie or Sterling bonds, or for the brave Brazilian Real.  But the long side of that bet is in flux.  If rates are rising, owning duration anywhere is costly.

Third, the real issue in correlation space is uncertainty with respect to the way stock and bonds will react.  They were positively correlated 1982 to 2007, and then negatively correlated subsequently.  We are in the midst of a state of flux that may see them highly positively correlated then inflect to mildly positive if rates rise.  Falling rates will signal stock losses as it will mean a new crisis.

Fifth, the signal to noise in markets is such that any single independent variable model (in this case the Yen) is too weak.

Best to build a solid asset mix and ignore the pundits.

Comment: We can ask; that doesn't mean we're going to get it. Oil companies don't have to invest their money here. We have to compete on the global market for industry investment, which means we don't get to just arbitrarily decide what percentage the state deserves, or we could just say we're going to take 100% and still receive the investment we want. Would you be surprised if no oil companies signed up to invest money in Alaska while receiving 0% of the revenue? Then don't be surprised if some don't for 50% because it's just as irrational to assume that's what the state deserves, regardless of what the markets dictate. There very well could be an economic climate at sometime that warrants Alaska getting a larger cut. But we can't just demand it. Also, your share of that thing that belongs to you is worthless sitting in the ground without someone else doing the work for you, so basically you're owed nothing from anyone.

Comment: PHILCO3: I'm not surprised that job applicants with foreign names don't get call backs at the same rate as those with European names. (The term "WASP" is actually quite irrelevant in the Canadian context. I was born and raised here and even though an Anglophone don't have a WASP surname, which was never a disadvantage as far as I could ascertain.) During my working years, I sat on a few hiring committees and the two things that impacted consideration of immigrant applicants arose from concerns about English language skills and educational equivalency. The first issue is logically self-explanatory while the latter is relevant because it's often difficult for employers to assess the actual qualifications of applicants who are educated and/or trained outside of Canada. Neither issue ever stopped an organization with which I was affiliated from considering immigrant applicants, but even if only subconsciously these differences probably do generate barriers. It's human nature.

Comment: There have always been good reasons to be mistrustful of the media; Chomsky said this well years ago in "Manufacturing Consent".  And there has never been a media outlet without some sort of bias.  I don't know if it's really being 'taken to extremes' these days or not; there's always been crazy stuff.
At the same time, some sources are obviously better than others.  I'd trust the G&N, NYT, The Economist, The Guardian, The Wall Street Journal, etc., long, long before I'd trust Fox, The Rebel, The Drudge Report, Young Turks, or Breitbart.  The first group has earned a degree of credibility and will often carry opposing views; the second simply popped up to promote specific agendas.
There is a "meme" claiming 'Muslim refugees' get paid more than a Canadian pensioner.  It has been proven untrue repeatedly, yet still appears from time to time with comments like, "disgusting" or "shows who Trudeau cares about."  When people accept memes as facts, a problem lies with with consumers of media.

Comment: The Tigers would have taken on a significant portion of paying the contract. Especially if they wanted some good prospects. You don't get many facts about baseball trades yourself. Comment: "our corporate rates are already lower than most in the USA"

Given that the U.S. has the highest corporate tax rate in the developed world this isn't exactly saying much.

The combined corporate tax rate in Ontario, at 26.5%, is slightly higher than both the average (mean) and median tax rate among developed countries, though not by much.  Last I checked the mean was about 26.0% and the median was about 25.0%.  Probably not a big deterrent but also not an incentive.

Ohh, and corporations are DEFINITELY leaving the U.S. due to their high corporate tax rate.  That is why Burger King merged with Tim Hortons to move their headquarters to Canada and why Pfizer almost moved their headquarters to the U.K. before new rules blocked them.  Many more corporations simply never setup in the U.S. from the get go.

Comment: "Has anyone ever done a study on the average IQ of people who believe you can sail off the edge of the planet?"

Yes: in fact there are several studies on the subject, and several books on the subject. Researchers found that people who believe that which they know to be false are not low-IQ: in fact they tend to be average intelligence, and therefore score average on IQ tests.

Being wrong, and actively resisting being correct, and knowing one is wrong but still insisting one is not wrong, is not a matter of intelligence: several other factors are involved.

Comment: Debt to GDP ratio or balanced budgets may be good economic indicators, however neither speaks to the most important factor in every country and that is living conditions.  Wilkinson and Pickett  came up with a thorough analysis using living conditions based on eleven different health and social problems: physical health, mental health, drug abuse, education, imprisonment, obesity, social mobility, trust and community life, violence, teenage pregnancies, and child well-being. They found,  among developed countries there was no correlation between wealth and living conditions. For example, Japan, an economic basket case, and Sweden tied for top place as the place to live. The US, the wealthiest developed country, was in last place along with Portugal, as a place to live.

There was correlation, unexplained, between income inequality(top 20% income divided by bottom 20% income) and living conditions. The lower the inequality, the better the living conditions. 

That needs exploring.

Comment: The 1967 Centennial celebrations under Lester Pearson seem to have been an attempt to reinvent Canada under the Liberals, who regarded themselves as a permanent "natural governing party". This followed the flag introduced under Pearson in 1965.

Just as the distribution of Senate seats is unfair to the West, the adoption of the maple leaf was an artefact of the original merger, appearing for example on the reverse of Victorian coins (i.e. 1876 one-cent piece) strangely as a wreath of maple leafs,-- something to think about as a crafts challenge for those raking leaves next fall in the southern latitudes of Ontario and Québec.   

Given that the maple doesn't grow indigenously over most of Canada's land mass, one of the coniferous species might have been a more practical and perhaps fairer choice,-- unless of course, the West decides to leave in frustration over Trudeau II.

Comment: Thank you for making my point. I agree that "accurate description demands objectivity".

But from the substance of your reply, it appears that you do not. While the word "alien" may conjure up any number of colloquial definitions, including beings from Outer Space, that's precisely the problem: when we use the term "illegal aliens", it is to specify legal status, not to suggest, one way or another, whether they "belong" here in the moral sense. 

As I pointed out in my initial response, one can either be a citizen of a country or an alien - that is, without the privileges of citizenship. Similarly, one can be in a country legally or illegally. There are no other options. Simple, objective, and clear. An editor's dream, no?

Need an example? A non-resident alien can buy an Alaska hunting license. There is no such thing as an "undocumented immigrant" license.

Although you appear wish otherwise, the USA does have borders and immigration laws. Even editors should be able to observe that.

Comment: It is incredibly subjective to assert that liturgical dance equates to "ecstasy of immersion in the restorative grace of boundless mercy and joy".  Even people I know who support liturgical dance would call that a stretch.  Dance in praise of God in scripture was a spontaneous expression of praise, not some choreographed, billowy performance.  And, the Mass provides us with another way to participate in redemptive grace.  It's called the Eucharist.  By receiving the Eucharist, Christ unites us to his resurrected self physically and spiritually.  Why would we "strain a gnat but swallow a camel" by trying to equate liturgical dance to such benefits when it's right there before us staring us in the face?  Actual participation in the Mass means participating in what God already provides us in the Mass, not inventing some other shiny object and calling it active participation for its "incarnational" quality of creating ecstasy and joy or whatever.

Comment: What you say is wishful thinking. Whistling past the graveyard. 

Consent is required. Canada is a 'full and unreserved' signatory to UNDRIP which is entirely clear on the matter of "free, prior and informed CONSENT". 

Canada would love to 're-interpret' UNDRIP but they can't. You can't unilaterally change the terms of an international treaty. So, the Trudeau Liberals are dragging their feet implementing the treaty (although we're bound by it), the Courts are dragging their feet, and Canadians like yourself continue to falsely deny the veracity and inevitability of UNDRIP.

There is no discussion in our Constitution about 'consultation, accommodation, and compensation'. That's simply a convention established in the SCOC that everyone knows is inadequate and unsupported in Canadian law. It's simply another way the courts perpetuate an illegal 'colonial' status quo.

It's unceded Indigenous land - without a treaty it's not Crown land. Natives have a right of veto on their land.

Comment: No, that wasn't the original budget for the airport. It was about $3.4 billion in hard construction costs. A significant portion of the "over budget" DIA was not hard construction costs but additional capitalized interest that had to be incurred during the 14 months of delayed opening. That alone was something like a billion dollars.

The $1.8 billion is the payout over 34 years for the Great Hall project. It is like paying your home mortgage. Over 30 years, you pay a heck of a lot more to the bank than the principal amount of your mortgage. The capital cost of the Great Hall work, comparable to the $3.4 billion to construct DIA, is $650 million, not $1.8 billion. The $650 million is part of the $1.8 billion, the rest being the operations and maintenance payments over 30 years.

Comment: In 2012, 2.6 million board feet was logged from state forests in Linn County. In 2015, 12.4 million feet were logged from state forests, nearly a 400% increase! A total of 29 million board feet was logged from Linn County's public lands in 2012. In 2015, a total of 54 million feet was logged from public lands, an 86% increase.  These significant logging increases on Linn Co. public forests over the last 3 years make it difficult to understand the urgency or even the need for their commissioners' lawsuit.

By contrast, 215 million board feet was logged from Linn County industry owned lands in 2015. Since 1999, industrial owners of over 5,000 acres (this includes nearly all of Linn's industrial ownership) have not had to pay the harvest privilege tax... a multi-million dollar revenue loss to Linn County. What do Linn's commissioners have to say about this?!

Comment: Ok, You can stand against both practices, but any attempts to compare the two as equivalent practices when they are not takes away from the unique seriousness of female "circumcision/mutilation,” as most cases of FGM involve the partial or complete removal of the genitalia, done at a developmentally vulnerable stage, which makes intercourse extremely difficult and painful, and can be the cause of a number of serious medical complications, including not only haemorrhage but also urinary retention, urinary infection, wound infection, and septicaemia, hepatitis, and tetanus, as well as being "always torture" and taking a year to heal. 

I DON'T condone circumcision, I'm just cautioning against labelling it as morally equivalent to FGM - the INTENT is a fundamental difference between these practices. FGM is "to control the girl’s sexuality, maintaining purity" - oppressive, controlling, subjugation. Circumcision is done mostly "as a religious/cultural ritual", an innately neutral intent.

Comment: If properly designed and implemented, value capture can promote more affordable development near transit.  Some communities have achieved this by transforming their property tax into a value capture fee.  This is accomplished by reducing the tax rate applied to privately-created building values while increasing the tax rate applied to publicly-created land values.  The lower rate on buildings makes them cheaper to construct, improve and maintain.  This is good for residents and for businesses.  Surprisingly, the higher rate on land helps keep land prices more affordable by reducing the profit from land speculation and thereby reducing the speculative demand for land.  

For more info, see "Funding Infrastructure to Rebuild Equitable Green Prosperity" at http://revitalizationnews.com/article/funding-infrastructure-for-sustainable-equitable-revitalization/

Comment: The bill would replace state winner-take-all laws that award all of a state’s electoral votes to the candidate who get the most popular votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), in the enacting states, to a system guaranteeing the majority of Electoral College votes for, and the Presidency to, the candidate getting the most popular votes in the entire US. 
		
The bill retains the constitutionally mandated Electoral College and state control of elections, and uses the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes. It ensures that every voter is equal, every voter will matter, in every state, in every presidential election, and the candidate with the most votes wins, as in virtually every other election in the country.
	
Every vote would matter in the state counts and national count.

Comment: I helped found KindTree - Autism Rocks 20 years ago. KindTree produces their annual Friends and Family Camp every year near the end of August at the Baker Boy Scout Camp on Siltcoos Lake south of Florence. This is the "deserted island" Laura was hoping for. The real world fades away and you realize you are at a family reunion of a family you didn't know you had. A family that understands and celebrates everyone's uniqueness - people on the spectrum, their caregivers and the volunteers who organize and staff the camp. You are not really alone.
It's a magical event.
KindTree also offers educational groups in their Skill Training for an Independent Living Experience (STiLE) program that help many folks develop skills they need, and an Art Program that allows autistic artists to show and market their work. They do more, too.
All designed to "serve and celebrate people on the autism spectrum." Gather your strength, offer your love" is their way. For all of us.
kindtree.org

Comment: Fortunately I am retired from my Vancouver business, so I am no longer directly impacted by the crippling tax burden on small and medium sized businesses in this city. 
However it annoys me that so many Canadians do not understand that increased taxes on those that provide essential services and products to those living here are simply passed on to the user of the services and products. In many cases, the property tax bill for small retail operations is now close to the cost of the rent of the property and it has made it more or less impossible to start a new small business in the city - it is among the main causes as to why so many of our existing small and middle sized businesses are failing. 
The result is that we are losing businesses that actually pay property tax, income tax and that employ people in the community. Instead we have multi nationals who employ nobody in the city, who pay no property to tax and who for the most part take their profits in low tax jurisdictions.

Comment: Nah - the whole baseload thing is largely overblown. It's ridiculously easy to solve. The only time it's an issue is if neither the sun nor the wind is available - which happens exceedingly rarely.

So solving those rare in-betweens becomes much, much easier. Let's assume we can't do it with storage. Okay - so we need baseload power, but we don't need a LOT of it, we only need it as a backup for low-use times (night) when it is ALSO windstill. 
Build four or five natural gas generators. Those things can spin up at a moments notice, and spin down again when you don't need them. Can stand idly in between without problems (these are all things that you cannot do with coal or nuclear). And while they do produce CO2 it's much less than coal produces - and they'll be running so rarely that the impact would be negligible. 
We don't even have to mine the gas. We'll be using so little it's more economic to buy it from Mozambique which has lots of the stuff already.

Comment: Homeland Securty -- "Naturalization Through Military Service: Fact Sheet
Special provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) authorize U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) to expedite the application and naturalization process for current members of the U.S. armed forces and veterans. Generally, qualifying military service includes service with one of the following: Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, Coast Guard and National Guard. In addition, spouses of members of the U.S. armed forces who are or will be deployed may be eligible for expedited naturalization. Other provisions of the law also allow certain spouses to complete the naturalization process abroad.

Comment: I fully get your point.  Balance to you means folks that are not consumptive users of game.  Yet you assume that the board of game controls the entire F&G budget and gets all the money.  It does not.  Those funds are disbursed throughout their budget for other things like habitat restoration, research, shooting ranges, etc., many things that have nothing to do with the Board of Game.  So your point is invalid.  If you want to have a voice in how shooters funds are used, feel free to call F&G, or your local Advisory Council.

But make no mistake, the reason that F&G does get those matching funds is directly due to the fact that they have to match those funds with hunting and fishing license fees and those hunting and fishing fees must stay within F&G.  So you can whine all you want about shooters, but the fact is those funds come to F&G due to hunters and fishermen, yet help shooters, boaters, viewers, and campers as well.

Comment: If you are buying with cash, yes, buying a slightly used car would tend to be a better value.  However, if you need to finance, and this is probably the case, it may actually be cheaper to buy new.  Why?  Well, interest rates for financing a new car over 5, 6, even 7 years are as low as 0%.  On the other hand, interest rates for financing used cars tend to be much high, up to 5, 6, even 7%.  Add to this the fact that you get a full warranty and many new cars come with considerable incentives that lower the price and you may discover that owning a new car is in fact the better choice.

Comment: Rob slightly mis-states what the adjustedcostbase.ca website will do for you.

You don't need the premium service for it to give you an annual report of capital gains and losses.  The basic free service will do that for you.

What the premium service gives you is it fixes the 'phantom distributions' or reinvested capital gains.  It has those numbers in its database, and you just have to instruct it to add them to your portfolio, for each holding.  (So it's not quite fully automatic.)  This is good, because it saves you time, and it may save you money.

For what it's worth, it also has return of capital in its database, although RoC is less of a pain to update.  The numbers are updated early every year, in time for tax season.

Whoever runs that site does a great service to Canadian DIY investors.  It's a good site to use and support.

Comment: Mr. Oppegaard alludes to something that speaks to me personally with his anecdote concerning his guest lecture. I read multiple news sources daily and well as professional journals (I do receive some journals in print as a result of professional memberships) and some magazines such as the New Yorker. That said, it’s been years since I’ve opened a printed newspaper. In fact, now, printed journalism seems to me to be frustratingly two-dimensional. It’s difficult to fact-check or follow up in more depth from print media. I believe that in order to survive in a connected world, journalism will need to fundamentally change. One of my criticisms of the Star-Advertiser (in addition to the numerous grammatical and spelling errors and clumsy use of language) is that the online version seems to be treated as an afterthought because everyone else is doing it rather than their vehicle to the future of journalism.

Comment: YIKES!!! You sure have had some interesting escapades!
Well, spiders are the things that send me into a tailspin. I don't care if they're the size of a pinhead or of a dinner plate, we are immediately in different rooms.
I used to go looking for arrowheads on my in-law's farm in the Ozarks. It was wayyy off the county road with  oak, hickory and other huge trees, abandoned fields and cow pastures. Through it ran a clear creek with many deer and wild turkeys which seemed to like to fly up out of nowhere just to scare the pee-wadin out of a guy. One day I glanced down and there sat a red orb-weaver on my shirt. I doubt he has re-entered Earth's atmosphere yet!  Never did see any snakes but I know for a fact there were rattlers in the big old oak barn and cottonmouths by the creek. Every time it rained I found a lot of terrific arrowheads and spearheads in place next to the creek where the Osage once sat and made them.
 I will always love that old farm. It's near Quincy, Missouri.

Comment: By restricting your housing choice to apartment buildings, you are guaranteeing that 'working-class' people are perpetually at the mercy of those owning those buildings. Relying on the 30% subsidy from the Federal Government just adds the additional dependence Boozer ranted against earlier.  That perpetuates dependence rather than independence.

Comment: Linda, you must not live in Port Angeles or on the peninsula to think the majority of the fluoride opposition group here is libertarian. Perhaps you don't understand what the term means though since nobody who would self-identify as a libertarian would claim the right to deprive anyone of the choice to put a substance in their own body or use force to add any against their will.

Water in it's natural state, free of contamination such as lead and arsenic is healthful and essential to life. Water supply source points can contain harmful levels of lead, arsenic, copper, sulfur, fluoride and more from naturally occurring conditions alone. Water providers or those on a private well filter out excess harmful contaminants at the source point. The city is knowingly adding some of the impurities mentioned above by fluoridating.

Nobody wants to deprive anyone of fluoride if they want it. Numerous freely-available oral care products contain it, as well as rinses by prescription from a doctor.

So the ratio is much lower than you are mentioning. 

The facility pays rent  (incl.outdoor space), benefits to the employees, they are required to maintain toys, play structures, change facilities, sleeping facilities, educational material and provide food with a minimum nutritional value for 3 meals and 2-3 snacks a day.  That all adds up.

So I paid $14,000 for my oldest son. His class of 15 -$210,000/year. With 4 full staff for his room and 1 part-time staff that's $47,000/year/staff but then take out rent/maintenance/food/benefits (they actually make $32K). And in the GTA that's not a lot.

Everything I mentioned is a min. gov't requirement.

Comment: I agree Dennis. Philosopher Martha Nussbaum has written a highly relevant book - "Not for Profit: Why Democracy Needs the Humanities."  Much as Sister Joan has alluded to, Nussbaum argues that  the humanities are essential to education because they are essential for creating competent citizens who can think critically and become knowledgeable and empathetic citizens.  She suggests that the current shortsighted focus on profits (and tracking into business schools) has eroded our ability to criticize authority, reduced our sympathy with the marginalized, and damaged our competence to deal with complex global problems.  The loss of these basic capacities jeopardizes the health of democracy and the hope of a decent world.

Comment: It's great to see the attention this is receiving at the national level. It is also important to note several grass roots initiatives that are striving to achieve the same goals. Concussion U  (https://concussionu.wordpress.com) is an interest group founded by 5 medical students at Memorial University of Newfoundland with a common goal: to make sports safer for youth.  These individuals are very active in promoting head injury awareness and prevention in schools and youth sports organizations. As many of them are young athletes themselves with their own "concussion stories" they are, I believe, able to make a real impact on other young athletes. 
I would be great to to see these grass roots initiatives linked together with the  national  agenda. The message and the outcomes could be much more powerful.

Comment: Its not one or the other.  I hold divid. payers in reg'd and non-regd accounts.  Solid blue chip divid. paying stocks add stability &  lower volatility to your portfolio while at same time a decent capital appreciation. They're usually less risky than growth stocks (no or very-low dividend payers) and provide greater total returns over the long term.  That's what I want in my registered accounts; less gambling.  My non-reg'd accounts are skewed with growth stocks to take advantage of the more tax-efficient capital gains.  Its worked great for me over past 20 yrs.

Comment: Manahattan real estate is a big deal, but high prices there are also about A LOT more than real estate. The opportunity to do so many different things at a high level in Manahattan is staggering, so there's demand to live there.

Vancouver is ONLY about real estate - and real estate is only thriving here as it does because governments have crafted policies that have focused massively on economic growth in this sector (whether those policies are related to debt or immigration). There is very little economic energy here outside that sector (thus real estate/construction now accounts for about 1/3 of BC's economy - which should terrify people who reflect for even 30 seconds).

I agree loss of gas stations is a natural outcome of spiked values. But the demand that exists in places like NYC is because there is demand to actually live there and do cool work. The demand in Vancouver has a lot less to do with shelter and a lot more to do with speculation and creating a hedge for foreign money.

Comment: Fair point.  I have read this evidence very carefully and have found it wanting.  The primary study quoted is a retrospective analysis involving a relatively small sample size performed over a decade ago in a single center and prior to fentanyl being a player.  These types of studies are confounded by bias.  Given the sample size, an alternate outcome can be achieved simply by statistical chance alone.  The scientific purpose of the study was to show that safe-injection sites reduce mortality.  Current evidence - anecdotal because it is not obtained as part of a rigorous scientific process, but very real nonetheless - indicates that death rates have INCREASED substantially after the introduction of safe injection sites, thereby confounding the study results.   I understand what 'anecdotal evidence' means in practice and I also understand the limits of scientific studies, my own included.

Comment: At one time long ado Fan of Reality I would have agreed that the City should look to reinvigorate Eastgate. Indeed if you rummage around the City of Bellevue website you'll find the requisite planning documents produced by the usual committees that recommend various courses of action. It makes for quite dry reading. In reality Eastgate is a hodgepodge of auto dealerships, corporate parks, extended stay hotels and a recently opened marijuana store.

At one time the City tried its hand at “neighborhood shopping center revitalization.” The result was Walmart replacing K-Mart at Kelsey Creek and an overwrought white elephant that is now Lake Hills Shopping Center.
