Comment: I used to fly a lot for work earlier in my career,  both domestically and internationally. There are things I found to be universally true. I never found a single airline that was perfect but some are definitely better than others. Alaska definitely falls into that "better" class. The other thing I found was how the passenger reacted to a bad situation often determined their outcome. When things were going wrong and I  had to work with an agent to fix things I always found being calm, a little sympathetic to their situation and a little flexible went a long way. These agents ars just people like you and I with a limited capacity to fix things. When a flight gets cancellled they suddenly have several hundred unhappy people to deal with. Being demanding, boorish and sometimes utterly rude to them won't  necessarily change their options. I once followed a guy who screamed how important he was at an agent. While she couldnt get him on the next flight she got me on ..upgraded to 1st class!!

Comment: Scott, thank you for your recommendations!  
I think the same thing happens when people from outside of SEAlaska (Anchorage, Fairbanks etc.) come here to hike around or backpack into the wilderness areas in the Tongass National Forest or Misty Fjords National Monument. We have wonderful trails but every now and then people decide to go off the trails. 
Sometimes they are rescued and sometimes are recovered. 
In a temperate rainforest all sorts of things can be covered up by branches and leaves. 
Step on a rotten log, you end up in a hole with a broken leg. 
Going off trail often results in stepping on very slippery, wet moss, which can cause you to slide over the edge with a six hundred foot drop.
 Our unique weather conditions change so quickly, being prepared for the rain and high winds can be a life saver.
I have seen experienced hikers of from other areas come here and get screwed up, so I figure going to unfamilar territory like a glacier, it would be prudent to go with a expert.

Comment: I love our state university system; the school has been part of my life (more than 60 years). What I'm going to say may hurt feelings, but I this needs to be said:

When I initially enrolled at the university in 1976, the cost of tuition was $200. for as many credits as a student wanted to carry; the total cost was $1,200 which included all college related costs each semester.

I realize there has been inflation in the ensuing years, but what has happened is tragic: our university seems to have lost its student focus. About 10 years ago, I was in Ketchikan where a system wide administrator's meeting was being held: It looked for all the world that several of these folks wore $10,000 suits; Cashmere coats were the inn-thing.

I love the other parts of our home as well and will offer this insight: it appears to me that the group we begin calling the (HIPP-WA-ZEE) in the early 1980s has taken over our home: we live in a whole new reality we can't afford and nobody wants to pay for. FOCUS!

Comment: Also, regarding finding a cure.

Prevention is the best way to go for now.   Years ago, researchers in Europe were expecting stem cell therapies to be available for trials by 2020.   Last I heard, this wasn't in the cards.

The mechanisms around sensori-neural hearing loss (the loss Digby suffers from) are among the most complicated in the body.   It's best to do whatever you can to preserve hearing including strengthening innate immune function rather than rely upon the hoped for development of a cure.   It may take a while.

Comment: You'll note a plethora of emotional rhetoric and a dearth of empirical data cited by our anti-ANWR op-ed writers. Even anecdotal evidence fails to support their cause as caribou search out gravel pads and roads as insect relief areas or Southern Beaufort Sea polar bears den at gravel pads and landfill sites. Nor do the vast majority of Inupiat people (who actually live on and adjacent to the coastal plain) share their views.

And interestingly enough, many of the most vocal opponents derive a portion of their living from guiding and so-called "eco tourism" in ANWR.

Comment: Undeclared, For all the bad mouthing of SB21 there has been no mention regarding the good that came of SB21. And though I don't feel that we can incentivize exploratory drilling at this time, the drilling definitely benefits our State. Before SB21 Anchorage and South Central were faced with impending Brown Outs because of depleted Cook Inlet natural gas. Because we incentivized drilling, major gas was found we are now exporting and Nikiski is booming again. South Central is now energy secure for many years to come. Also the Trans Alaska Pipe Line is running 1/4th full which creates operational problems. Not to mention the possibility of a possible shut down in the future. Less oil in pipe means less royalty money to fight over.

Comment: MSW - thank you for a well reasoned opinion piece and for the links especially Goodheart at Politico.  His analysis and thorough outline of history balances off many of the comments.

Take exception to this - ".....how those same statues are now being removed in a different attempt to whitewash history."   A few points - assuming you don't agree with a local rush to remove (Baltimore example) or no provision made to use statues in an agreed upon museum or cemetery setting with appropriate historical markers (e.g. Lost Cause, Jim Crow era, KKK erections/payments, end of Reconstruction and 1876 election, etc.).

In fact, Politico ran a US map with locations of the 700+ statues - almost all are in the deep south (TX to VA).  Groups have been aware and pushing to deal with many of these statues for years (so, no rush).  Would add another element - those same states need their state textbook committees to include correct history in books going forward - that alone will be a test.

Comment: I am in agreement with your logic, however, I would like to take it several steps further and blame the system that the person arose out of who conditioned the person. People do not exist in vacuums, they are the product of complex relationship dynamics over generations within cultural systems.  It is literally not the fault of the individual for being part of a family/societal system in which he was likely taught/conditioned that violating another person is normal, it is also likely not the fault of this person's parents but the larger societal context and inter-generational dysfunction in which the family arose out of. This does not mean, however, that the individual should not be held accountable although the entire system is at fault for this sort of behavior.  I place the blame on a violent culture that reifies separatism, individualism, competition, masculine dominance, and materialism, among others.  The individual is a product of these societal dysfunctions.

The Good News about America's Record Household Debt Levels

Bees knees, are Americans ever accomplished borrowers.

Comment: Ms. Willis,
With all due respect, you're argument doesn't make sense to me. Senator Wielechowski's lawsuit is in regard to Governor Walker's line item veto of a statute; a written law passed by Alaska state legislators.
While the state constitution does provide Governor Walker with a limited legislative function by way of the line item veto or, in other words, the authority to strike or reduce "items" in an appropriations bill, surely it does not allow the governor to upend statutes. 
It's no coincidence that there are 3 branches of government: the executive branch (enforces the law), legislative branch (makes the law), and the judicial branch (interprets the law). The 3 branches act as a check and balance on the other in order to prevent tyranny of one over the other. Senator Wielechowski by bringing this lawsuit is acting in good faith and we should all be thankful. 
This can't be an appropriation bill! It contains general legislation.

Comment: I can't disagree with anything in the article.

This trend, though, of eating on the go, eating out of a box, and having everyone operate on vastly different schedules, is damaging to western society.  Remember having a sit down family home-cooked dinner?  Remember when everything was closed on Sundays?

We can't turn back the clock, but we should be wary of embracing these changes as a society.  It is damaging to the family unit, it causes stress as people are running around like rats because they are switched on 24 hours a day, and it disconnects people from their fellow citizens.

I'm certainly no "religious right" (I'm athiest and politically centrist), but having a stay at home parent (male or female) cooking meals and running the household, looking after the kids and a somewhat "normal" daily and weekly schedule along with enough time in your day to sit down, take your mind off of work and eat a meal with friends, coworkers, family, or colleagues benefits all of society.

Comment: I've made vegan ice cream several times for friends and family. Making something that tastes good is easy. The trick is getting a consistency similar to the real thing, which is more difficult. What I have found is that the mixture must be a similar thickness and composition to traditional ice cream before it goes into the ice cream maker. Most recipes I encounter online are too watery or too fat-free, so they are icy or don't have a creamy feeling.

The best strategy may be not to call it "ice cream" if it doesn't have cream. If you just call it "vegan frozen dessert" you will set expectations correctly and everyone will be happy.

Comment: This decision has far reaching impacts. Under the Mag Stevens Act the fed govt has sole responsibility and duty to manage salmon within the fed waters throughout their migratory range in state waters. That includes the Kenai River. Any management plan that fed agencies come up must address this obligation. One of the federal standards for any plan prohibits discrimination of non residents from having equal access to the fisheries. Right now participation in the dip net fishery is limited to residents. The Feds cannot allow that to continue and still be in compliance with the law. So, You should at least contemplate or even worse, expect that the dip net fisheries on the Kenai will have non resident participation. As if it is not already a zoo for a couple of weeks. Think about two or three times more dip netters in a small area!

Comment: "While most states make similar exemptions for legislators, 12 states, including Oregon and Idaho, expect their lawmakers to comply with public records laws."

But not Washington.  And most states have this exemption for the same reason it exists in effect at the federal level.  We live in a constitutional republic, a *representative* form of government.  Our citizens have every right to participate in the electoral process to chose who represents us in making the law of the land.  

But they don't have every right to *every* detail of the sausage making that is the legislative process, nor should they IMO.  FOI laws unarguably protect the interests of the citizens and give them an important "check" against their government.  But there needs to be limits, or already stalemated legislatures would be even more incapable of negotiating solutions to problems. 

Voters have another check, every couple of years at election time.  In any case, this issue shouldn't be for the courts to decide.

Was her family comforted by the focus on her as sinner instead of as a kind, loving young woman, a daughter, sister, friend and wife? Comment: The writer identified some options available to the Government of Canada. Our Constitution explicitly provides another option (which Quebec could not overcome by using the override in s. 33 of the Charter).  The 1867 Constitution (the one we just celebrated Canada 150 for) contains an extraordinary  clause allowing the federal Government to disallow any provincial law within one year of it being passed. Lest you think the power has not been used, it was used 66 times between 1867 and 1896, 30 times between 1896 and 1920 (19 of those times when BC took racist measures against its Chinese, Japanese and Sikh populations) and 16 times between 1920 and 1943, when it was last used to disallow a WWII Alberta law against land sales to Hutterites and "enemy aliens".  Decades ago, there was pressure on PM Trudeau Sr to disallow the Quebec language law.

Not saying that PM Trudeau Jr would do this, but it's a 'legal' (albeit probably not politically palatable) option.

Comment: Yes, every other industrialized nation in the world has the same problems we have: an aging population, a declining workforce participation rate, a declining birth rate, and costs of social welfare programs growing 3 times faster than our economies, and more debt than they've ever had before.

The Fed as masked the cost of our debt with artificially low interest rates.  If the interest cost of servicing the debt were at the same rate today as it was in 2000 (6.34%, which seemed low at the time), our deficit would be $1.2 Trillion larger than it is.  Knowing those low rates have distorted markets, creating bubbles in stocks, bonds, and housing, the Fed is in the process of normalizing rates, which will increase the deficits, and probably crash all three bubbles.

When that happens, expect a world wide Depression and a likely collapse of the world economic system that will make 2008 look like a walk in the park.  Entire countries are defaulting, and we've got states and cities close.

Comment: The GCI Great Alaska Shootout was my first time in the Alaska Airlines Center and my first time watching basketball in person in about a decade. The rest were good games especially Nevada's come back vs Oakland and the last two games!  Based on a bit of googling, the seating capacity of the AAC is 5000.  Given the attendance number in the article the arena was about 65% full at peak for the championship game.  For the rest of the days it hovered around 50% for the most attended evening sessions.  I hope this tournament is viable in the future!

Comment: ThomasNicholls: Or maybe, as an immigrant, she was more thoughtful and contemplative in her analysis of the role of the hereditary British monarchy in Canada's political psychology and system of governance? The role of a citizen in a democracy is not merely to obey (there are a lot of despotic regimes in which that's a requirement), but instead is to think and act independently. Thankfully, the judge who presided at my mother's citizenship ceremony was an independent thinker. In response to my mother's clearly stated objection to the royal oath, he said "They're only words, dear. Hold your nose." He obviously didn't believe her views would detract from her value as a diligent Canadian citizen. My mother was proud of stating her objection, often noting that she became a Canadian under protest. It was a spirit she never lost throughout the remainder of her life.

Comment: Again Ms. Wente is full of hyperbole and factless opinion when she states:

“Our electricity costs are through the roof,” she told me. The reason is something called “global adjustments” – a fee to cover the cost of green energy and conservation programs that is unrelated to the actual cost of electricity itself. Companies like hers are facing staggering hydro bills of $30,000 or $40,000 a month – mostly because of government investments in green energy that Ontario doesn’t need and can’t use."  

WIND AND SOLAR ACCOUNT FOR LESS THAN 1/4 OF THE GLOBAL ADJUSTMENT.  Natural Gas, Nuclear, and OPG account for the bulk of it.  New renewables alone are not the cause of higher electricity prices as she implies. 

Automatic Coatings derives revenue from coating pipelines so perhaps they aren't so fond of a shift away from fossil fuels.  The pipeline business also may be the impetus for moving south to Illinois that happens to  burn cheap dirty coal for 50% of their electricity.

Comment: I like these "questions for reflection" and growth from Fr Francis Fernandez, from In Conversation with God:

"- What is the true motivation of my actions? 
- What is my heart really set upon?
- Have I really tried to be detached from earthly goods, or on the contrary, do I suffer and complain when I am short of something?
- How quick am I to react against the slightest incitement to self-seeking and ease, promoted very often by the advertisements of the consumer society? 
-Am I sparing in my personal needs, do I put curbs on my extravagance, do I avoid frivolous and unnecessary purchases?
- Do I cheerfully accept whatever inconveniences me and the lack of means at my disposal? 
- Am I generous in giving alms to those who are in much worse circumstances? 
- Do I contribute to the support of good causes, depriving myself of things I would like to have...?

Only in this way will we live with the joy and freedom necessary if we are to be disciples of our Lord in the midst of the world."
